key_title: Key to the genera of Poaceae

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Monocotyledons

source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Poaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: From: Walsh, N.G. (1994). Poaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Creeping, rhizomic, silky-hairy perennial of coastal sands; plants dioecious; male spikelets subsessile, in slender racemes clustered at the nodes of the culm; female spikelets solitary near base of a long, stout bristle, many spikes together comprising a globular head to 25 cm diam. which breaks free entire and rolls tumbleweed-like with the wind

Plants not combining the above features, if ever dioecious, then either a very robust, tufted grass with very scabrous leaves and large plume-like inflorescence, or a creeping grass of damp, saline areas with strongly distichous leaves

A bamboo, with woody culms to c. 15 mm diam., much-branched in upper part; culm-leaves with sheaths distinctly mottled, blades not developed; upper branches each with up to 7 leaves to 17 cm long and about 1 cm wide, joining to their sheaths via a thickened, petiole-like base; not known to flower in Victoria; a garden-escape, currently known only from wet forest in the Dandenong Ranges east of Melbourne.
Plants not combining the above features, if ever bamboo-like, culms either unbranched or wider than 15 mm diam., and usually with evidence of recent flowering
Inflorescence a cluster of 2-6 spikelets, remaining wholly or largely enclosed and hidden within uppermost leaf-sheaths; vigorous, long-rhizomatous perennial (Kikuyu)
Inflorescence exposed beyond uppermost leaf-sheaths, if ever partly concealed, then with many more than 6 spikelets

Spikelets 2-flowered; rachilla not extending beyond the base of the upper floret; lower floret of spikelet male or barren, sometimes lacking a palea (in Eriochloa the lower glume reduced to a knob-like swelling at the base of the spikelet); upper floret bisexual or female and usually different in appearance from lower; spikelet dorsally compressed or broadly rounded on back, falling with glumes attached

Spikelets with 1-many florets; if 2-flowered, either the rachilla extending beyond the base of the upper floret, the lower floret bisexual, or spikelets falling free from glumes at maturity; spikelets commonly laterally compressed
Spikelets not paired, or if ever paired, both sessile or equally pedicellate and similar

Spikelets paired within the inflorescence, unequally pedicellate or with the lower spikelet sessile and the other pedicellate, the sessile and pedicellate spikelets usually dissimilar, occasionally the upper spikelet of each pair reduced, or rarely, absent and represented by a pedicel only

Inflorescence of several clusters of spikelets each subtended by a spathe-like bract; spikelets in groups of 7, the lower 4 male or sterile, surrounding a triad of 2 male spikelets and 1 awned bisexual spikelets (Kangaroo Grass)
Inflorescence not as above; spikelets not grouped in 7s
All spikelets morphologically or functionally unisexual
At least some, and usually all spikelets bisexual (sometimes fertile spikelets subtended by sterile spikelets, or some florets within a spikelet may be unisexual or sterile)
Robust, tufted grass with coarsely scabrous leaf-blades and large plume-like inflorescences on culms at least 1 5 m high (Pampas Grass)
Creeping grass with strongly distichous leaves, usually of damp, saline areas
Spikelets of two kinds-fertile and sterile, the latter consisting of several bracts or empty lemmas, subtending the fertile spikelets; spikelets secund along branches of panicle
Spikelets homogeneous
Panicle lax; fertile spikelets pedicellate, 1-flowered; sterile lemmas obtuse, awnless
Panicle rigid; fertile spikelets subsessile, 2-4-flowered; sterile lemmas acuminate or awned
Spikelets in 2 rows, one row on each side of the axis (when spikelets several-flowered or grouped in threes, the inflorescence appearing almost cylindric)
Spikelets arranged all round the axis or in one or more rows along one side only of the axis
Spikelets paired, or in groups of 3 at nodes
Spikelets solitary at nodes of spike or raceme
Spikelets 3-6-flowered; glumes obtuse or barely pointed; robust, rhizomatous perennials
Spikelets 1-flowered; glumes awned or long-pointed; tufted annuals
Lemmas awned dorsally; leaves bearing soft, spreading hairs; axis of inflorescence breaking below each spikelet at maturity; annual of heavy soils, mostly western
Lemmas unawned or with a terminal awn
Lemmas 3-nerved, hyaline or thinly membranous
Lemmas 5-9-nerved, firm, more or less opaque
Lemma awnless
Lemma awned
Glumes paired; lemma inserted side-on to rachis (spikelet oriented laterally to axis)
Glume solitary, external; lemma inserted against the rachis (i.e. palea betweeen lemma and glume)
Glume solitary (only the terminal spikelet with 2 glumes), minute; ligule membranous; rachis scabrous-pubescent, jointed at each node; annual of sandy ground in west
Glumes paired, at least 1.5 mm long; ligule ciliate; rachis glabrous, unjointed; annual or perennial of dryish, usually rocky areas
Glume solitary; spikelet partially recessed into axis of spike
Glumes paired
Spikelets shortly pedicellate; lemma long-awned, 7-nerved; nodes of culm pubescent
Spikelets quite sessile; if lemma long-awned, then 5-nerved; nodes of culm glabrous
Annuals; spikes virtually cylindric; grain falling free from lemma and palea at maturity; cereals, mostly cultivated
Perennials; spikes distichous; grain remaining enclosed between lemma and palea
Spikelet 2-flowered; glumes very narrow, 1-nerved; lemma narrow, hairy along keel
Spikelet 2-5-flowered; glumes broad, 5-7-nerved; lemma broad, scabrous along keel
Axis of inflorescence fragile and readily breaking into segments at maturity, smooth along the acute lateral angles; sand-binder of coastal dunes
Axis of inflorescence tough, not readily breaking into segments, scabrous or pubescent along the lateral angles
Plants long-rhizomatous
Plants tufted or shortly rhizomatous
Glumes and lemmas obtuse; robust plants with stout culms usually 1 m high or more; usually cultivated or naturalized on salted land
Glumes and/or lemmas acute, mucronate or awned; smaller plants than above; native grasses
Axis of inflorescence pubescent between spikelets
Axis of inflorescence glabrous between spikelets or scabrous along the angles only
Lemma distinctly 3-9-lobed, the lobes sometimes terminating in awns
Body of lemma entire, bifid, or shortly 4-toothed, unawned, or with up to 5 awns
Spikelets 2-several-fiowered but only the lower 1 or 2 florets in spikelet fertile; lemma with 9 short, rigid, plumose awns; panicle spike-like
Spikelets Lflowered; lemma 3- or 5-lobed
Lemma with 5 smooth or shortly scabrous awns, the central one longer and stouter than the others; palea awnless
Lemma with 3 ciliate awns or awn-tipped lobes; palea 2-lobed, the lobes resembling those of the lemma
Tall, reed-like grass with plumose panicles; florets surrounded by long, silky hairs; leaves mostly cauline; usually growing in wet or boggy sites
Habit various, other features not combined as above
Culms 1–2 cm diam. or more; lemma and palea villous; rachilla glabrous; plants rarely flowering in Victoria
Culms <1 cm (mostly about 5 mm) diam.; lemma and palea glabrous; rachilla plumose; plants reliably flowering annually in Victoria
Spikelets with 1 fertile floret, occasionally with 1 or 2 male or sterile florets above or below, usually dissimilar to the fertile floret
Spikelets with 2-several fertile florets
Spikelets with 3 or more florets

Spikelets with 2 fertile florets (rarely 3 in Avena and Trisetum which have geniculate, dorsal awns attached above midway on the lemma, and Erythranthera, a rare, diminutive grass of the high alps, with blunt or shallowly emarginate lemmas bearing a minute subapical awn)
Lemmas unawned (or awns microscopic in Rytidosperma)
Lemmas with awns exceeding 1 mm
Glumes longer than 15 mm
Glumes shorter than 15 mm
Panicle contracted and spike-like; alpine perennial
Panicle loose (contracted in Aim praecox); annuals or perennials
Lemma with slender apical awn and 2 shorter lateral bristles (delicate annual to c. 20 cm high)
Awn attached dorsally
Spikelets (excluding awns) less than 4 mm long; widespread annuals
Spikelets (excluding awns) greater than 4 mm long; perennials
Florets dissimilar; spikelet 8 mm long or more; awn of lower floret 10-20 mm long; occasional weed of cultivation with swollen, corm-like basal internodes
Florets similar; spikelet 4-6 mm long; awns shortly exceeding lemma; uncommon perennial grass of alps and subalps
Lemma oblong, membranous, truncate-denticulate; ligule membranous; small, delicate annual of drier areas, mostly western
Lemma ovate, firm; ligule ciliate; perennials
Spikelets hardly plump; lemmas not shining; inflorescence contracted with only 2-5 spikelets; very rare, high-alpine grass
Spikelets very plump; lemmas hard and shining; inflorescence relatively broad and open with numerous spikelets; aquatic or semi-aquatic grass, not alpine
Inflorescence an umbel of 3 or more laterally compressed spikes (occasionally with 1-several additional spikes below the umbel)
Inflorescence not umbellate
Axis of spike terminated by a spikelet; weeds usually of areas receiving copious summer water
Axis of spike terminating in a naked point; uncommon annual of far northwest
Inflorescence an interrupted spike with spikelets sessile in globose clusters; glumes subequal; lemmas mucronate to very shortly awned; glabrous annual, dubiously recorded for Wimmera
Spikelets variously pedicellate

Large tussock of dry, sandy areas of west and north-west, with very stiff, terete, needle-pointed leaves; inflorescence long and narrow, far exceeding the foliage; lemmas of the several- to many-flowered spikelets truncate or shallowly 2-lobed at summit, silky-hairy in the lower half, the mid-nerve occasionally exserted as a short point
Not combining features as above
Lemma notched at summit or deeply lobed, the mid-nerve exserted as an awn (sometimes minute) between the lobes, or awn dorsal
Lemma entire, erose or obscurely toothed at summit, but not distinctly notched or bilobed
Glumes shorter than or equalling lowest lemma
Glumes longer than lower lemma, often as long as whole spikelet (excluding awns)
Lemma with 3 subequal awns; panicle often purplish, soft and plumose; uncommon tufted perennial of north-west
Lemma with a single awn, if ever with apical bristles then these short relative to awn
Spikelet dorsally compressed; lemma almost flat dorsally, obtuse, with 2 short lateral lobes and a short, straight mucro between; lower margins silky-hairy
Spikelets laterally compressed; lemma keeled or raised dorsally, distinctly awned

Lemma 4-toothed at apex (the outer teeth sometimes obscure), or with 4 apical bristles in addition to the large (8 mm or more), distinctly dorsal awn; ligule generally greater than 4 mm long; perennial grasses of seasonally or permanently wet places
Lemma not 4-toothed at apex; awn short, or if greater than 8 mm then subterminal; ligule less than 4 mm long; annuals or perennials
Lower glumes and lemmas less than 5 mm (rarely to 6 mm) long; annuals of sandy ground and/or warmer districts
Lower glumes and lemmas more than 5 mm long; annuals or perennials
Glumes very unequal, the lower one minute, bristle-like; lemma narrow, almost cylindric, 3-4.5 mm long
Glumes subequal; lemma laterally compressed, 2-3 mm long
Spikelets mostly 3-flowered; glumes and lemmas thinly membranous; awn minute, subapical; ligule ciliate at apex; uncommon perennial of alps and subalps
Spikelets with more than 4 flowers; glumes and/or lemmas firm at least toward base; awn conspicuous, or if ever very short, then apical; ligule not ciliate at apex
Lemma rather deeply 2-lobed, with central awn geniculate, twisted at base, at least 5 mm long; lemma with hairs on dorsal surface in tufts or more or less covering surface
Lemma shortly notched apically, with awn much less than 5 mm long; lemma glabrous or with hairs confined to lower half and/or margins
Spikelets slender, 6-11-flowered; lemmas thin-textured, conspicuously 9- nerved; annual of sandy soils in low-rainfall areas
Spikelets plump, 2-6-flowered; lemmas firm, indistinctly nerved; uncommon to rare perennials of well-watered sites

Lemmas evenly covered on back in lower half with short, fine hairs; awn obliquely recurved at maturity; very rare grass from swamps in far east 55. Lemmas glabrous on back (sometimes with marginal cilia or tufts of hairs); awn remaining erect
Lemmas glabrous on back (sometimes with marginal cilia or tufts of hairs); awn remaining erect
Spikelets 7-14 mm long; lemmas smooth and shining dorsally; grass of damp or peaty soils in lowlands with culms exceeding 15 cm high
Spikelets to 3.5 mm long; lemmas glabrous but not shining; exceedingly rare grass of higher alps with culms to only 8 cm high

Lemma with acute or club-shaped hairs along the lower margins and sometimes on the lower dorsal surface; panicles spike-like, often both terminal and arising from lower nodes; panicles usually embraced by the sheaths of subtending leaves
Lemma and panicle not as above
Ligule a row of hairs; lemma 3-nerved
Ligule membranous; lemma 3-7-nerved
Spikelets very plump, pendent on very fine pedicels; glumes and lemmas rounded dorsally, almost circular, cordate at base
Spikelets slender, usually erect; glumes and lemmas distinctly longer than wide, never cordate at base
Spikelets and branchlets attached on one side only of major panicle branches; spikelets and branchlets stiff; lemmas awnless or shortly awned, never woolly toward base
Spikelets arranged all around axis, or if panicle ever appearing one-sided then lax; lemmas frequently awned or woolly toward base
Robust perennial; glumes and lemmas scabrous or bristly along keels; lemmas mucronate or shortly awned
Annuals to 15 cm high; glumes and lemmas smooth and glabrous; lemmas obtuse or truncate, awnless
Spikelet tapered slightly from the thick pedicel; glumes subequal; lemmas obtuse, thick, obscurely nerved, 2-3 mm long
Spikelet expanding abruptly from the pedicel; glumes unequal; lemmas truncate, rather thin and distinctly 5-nerved, 5-6 mm long
Glumes very unequal, acuminate; lemmas very narrow, long-awned; leaf-sheaths glabrous or  pubescent; anther 1
Glumes subequal or if ever quite unequal then at least lower leaf-sheaths pubescent; lemmas entire or shortly awned; anthers 3

Ligule 8-20 mm long; culms usually greater than lm high (up to c. 3 m); panicle loose, 15-50 cm long; lemmas obtuse, membranous at apex, strongly scabrous along the 5 nerves; short-lived grass mostly of disturbed sites in wettish mountain forests
Ligule less than 8 mm long; combined features otherwise not as above
[link through]
Lemma obtuse at apex, awnless
Lemma pointed at apex, often awned
Lemma keeled dorsally; thinly membranous at least about the apex
Lemma rounded dorsally, more or less firm throughout
Lemma membranous throughout, glabrous; palea as long as or longer than lemma; uncommon grass of alps and subalps
Lemma usually firm at least toward base, often with a tuft of cottony hairs and/or with short hairs on the body toward base
Tufted alpine perennial with well-developed papery obtuse ligule, flat leaves and lemmas that are glabrous apart from the ciliate lower margins
If ever tufted alpine and perennial, then either ligule not developed or narrow and acute, leaves mostly inrolled, or if ever flat, then lemma hairy to some extent beyond ciliate margins
Upper glume 1-nerved; lemmas distinctly 5-nerved; leaf-sheaths tubular in lower part, often with distinct transverse septa between longitudinal veins; grasses of freshwater swamps or drainage lines
Upper glume 3-nerved; lemmas obscurely 5-nerved; leaf-sheaths open to base, lacking transverse septa; grasses of wet, saline ground
Ovary hairy at apex; styles subterminal; at least the lower leaf-sheaths with soft, more or less reflexed hairs; mostly annuals
Ovary entirely glabrous; styles terminal; leaf-sheaths glabrous or with scattered hairs; perennials
Lemmas keeled toward apex; callus glabrous
Lemmas keeled throughout; callus pubescent
Panicles contracted and nearly spike-like; rhizomatous grass of coastal sand dunes
Panicles open; caespitose grasses of subalps or swampy lowland sites, but not coastal dunes
Inflorescence variously composed of spikes or spike-like racemes with the spikelets arranged on one side only; spikes commonly umbellately arranged
Inflorescence a raceme or panicle (sometimes very contracted and appearing spike-like but spikelets at least shortly pedicellate), never digitate
Glumes solitary (or rarely paired), much reduced, the lower a ± triangular, sometimes short-ciliate wedge (0.3–0.6 mm long), the upper glume smaller or usually absent; lodicules absent; stigmas 1
Glumes paired, equal to enequal in length; upper glume usually > 0.6 mm long; lodicules present in fertile florets; stigmas 2
Spikes paired or if spikes more than 2, then arising from several levels of main axis; rigid, strongly rhizomatous grasses of tidal mud-flats
Spikes arranged in umbels (sometimes paired in the fine-leaved, uncommon lawn grass Cynodon transvaalensis)
Spikelets 2-3 mm long, with 1 floret only; lemma awnless; rhizomatous perennials
Spikelets mostly greater than 3 mm long, with 1-several male or sterile florets above the bisexual floret; fertile lemma awned; tufted or stoloniferous annuals or perennials
Spikelets laterally compressed
Spikelets dorsally compressed
Glume solitary, hardened, completely enclosing the lemma and palea
Glumes paired, or if ever apparently solitary, not completely enclosing lemma and palea
Spikelets in shortly stalked pairs in a cylindric, spike-like inflorescence, the single glume with rows of stout, hooked bristles; rather rare annual of north­west
Spikelets solitary in a slender spike-like raceme, the glume smooth, often shining and blackish, sometimes shortly awned; distichous-leaved perennial of sea-shores and (rarely) inland salt-lakes
Inflorescence cylindric, showy, with spikelets falling intact, usually in clusters of 2-5, each spikelet subtended and exceeded by a tuft or involucre of scabrous or plumose bristles
Spikelets neither falling in clusters, nor subtended by long bristles

Fertile floret subtended by 1 or 2 barren or male lemmas-the spikelets then sometimes appearing to have 4 glumes (barren lemmas sometimes exceedingly small in Phalaris and true glumes minute in Microlaena)
Fertile floret never subtended by male or barren lemmas (occasionally a second male or sterile floret above fertile floret)

Glumes minute relative to spikelet, somewhat separated from the lemmas due to a bristly, elongated callus at the base of the lowest sterile lemma; both sterile lemmas long-awned; inflorescence usually weeping
At least the upper glumes one-fifth or more as long as spikelet, overlapping the lemmas; inflorescence various
Inflorescence a dense, many-flowered spike-like raceme or panicle; at least the upper glume exceeding the sterile lemmas
Inflorescence either a loose panicle or a slender, few(less than 20)-flowered raceme; glumes shorter than the sterile lemmas
Sterile lemmas longer than fertile floret, awned; glumes very unequal, membranous and shining, never winged; strongly coumarin-scented
Sterile lemmas rudimentary (sometimes only 1), unawned, shorter than the fertile floret; glumes equal, strongly flattened laterally, the prominent keel often produced into a wing; non-aromatic
Lower lemmas staminate; palea 1-nerved; strongly coumarin-scented; alpine bogs or dryish foothill forests
Lower lemmas barren; palea 2-nerved; non-aromatic
Inflorescence paniculate, usually many-flowered; anthers 6; tufted or rhizomatous weeds
Inflorescence a few-flowered raceme; anthers 4; trailing, ascending or climbing native grasses
Glumes absent; lemma 5-nerved, hispid along nerves, the closely recurved margins holding firmly the narrow palea; semi-aquatic grass, forming loose swards
Glumes present, paired but sometimes unequal
Spikelet falling as a unit (i.e. with glumes attached) at maturity
Glumes persisting on plant after remainder of mature spikelet has fallen

Spikelets with 2 (very rarely 3) florets, the lower bisexual, unawned, the upper male or sterile, awned; spikelets falling complete, with glumes attached; plants usually more or less covered with short downy hairs
Spikelets with a single floret
Glumes obtuse, awnless, connate at base; lemma with a dorsal, geniculate awn; palea absent
Glumes either acute and unawned or obtuse and finely awned, entirely free; lemma awnless or with a short, fine, terminal awn; palea present
Lemma awnless (but glumes sometimes awn-tipped)
Lemma awned (sometimes minutely so)
Glumes awned, with a row of coarse, erect bristles along the keel; inflorescence a dense, spike-like panicle
Glumes awnless
Glumes shorter than or equal to lemma; seed-coat free from seed when dry; panicle (except in S. caroli) spike-like
Glumes longer than lemma; seed-coat remaining closely adherent to seed

Spikelet dorsally compressed; lemma of firmer texture than glumes; panicle dense and spike-like; leaves sharp-pointed; robust, rhizomatous grass of sandy coastal sites, often planted as dune stabilizer
Spikelet laterally compressed; lemma of thinner texture than glumes; panicle open or contracted but not spike-like

Rachilla extension 30–100% of lemma length; inflorescence often breaking below the lowest branch and falling intact, acting as a wind-dispersed diaspore; palea well-developed at least 60% of lemma length;

Rachilla extension less than 20% of lemma length; inflorescence remaining intact until after spikelets mature; palea usually absent or minute (but developed in weedy, rhizomatous A. capillaris, A. gigantea and A. stolonifera)

Glumes plumose-hairy, gradually tapered to a fine bristle-point; lemma with 3 fine awns, the central longer than the lateral pair; panicle softly hairy, dense, ovoid, 1-7 mm long; velvety annual of near-coastal and inland sandy areas
Glumes glabrous, scabrous or shortly hairy; other combined features not as above
Awns 3 or 5, or the single awn 3-branched
Awn solitary, but sometimes inserted between 2 acute lobes
Awns 5, the central one larger than sometimes unequal lateral pairs, and spirally twisting at the base
Awns 3 or awn 3-branched
Awns very unequal, the central one much longer and stouter than the lateral ones; glumes several-nerved, the longer 35 mm long or more; grass of lowlands in east
Awns equal or subequal; glumes 1-nerved, not exceeding 30 mm in length; grasses of drier, rocky or sandy sites, mostly western
Glumes 3-7-nerved; awn quite terminal on lemma
Glumes 1-nerved; awn attached dorsally but sometimes very near apex of lemma
Lemma obovoid, truncate at apex, strongly scabrous (sometimes laterally ridged), to 3 mm long; awn attached nearer dorsal side of lemma summit
Lemma cylindric to narrowly ovoid, narrowed at apex, smooth or granular, if ever scabrous then 5 mm long or more; awn attached more or less centrally at apex
Lemma margins overlapping and covering palea; lemma surface more or less evenly scabrous
Lemma margins not overlapping, often exposing palea which has a narrow central groove; lemma suface with transverse scabrous ridges
Awn of lemma deciduous, but often retained within the tip of the narrowly incurved upper glume; lemma to 2 mm long, quite smooth and glabrous; callus blunt and glabrous
Awn of lemma persistent; lemma 3 mm long or more; callus sharp-pointed and covered with hairs
Summit of lemma forming a firm, cylindrical corona 0.5–2.5 mm long, terminated by a ring of erect bristles or spines; palea less than half as long as lemma; introduced species
Summit of lemma without corona, but sometimes with a fuft of soft hars at apex; palea usually more than half as long as lemma; native species

Awn less than 20 mm long; seed (caryopsis) plump, top-shaped, loosely enclosed within the lemma; rows of seed-like propagules (cleistogenes) borne in basal leaf-sheaths; introduced, weedy grass sometimes forming closed swards
Awn more than 20 mm long; seed (caryopsis) narrow, closely enclosed by lemma; cleistogenes not produced; native grasses
Awn 10 mm long or more; awn inserted between 2 (sometimes minute) apical lobes
Awn less than 10 mm long; awn commonly distinctly dorsal
Panicle bristly, very dense, ovoid or spike-like; awn rigid, erect
Panicle soft, open to contracted, rarely spike-like; awn fine, sinuate or geniculate
Ligule mostly longer than 2.5 mm long; at least the lower glume less than 2.5 mm long; anthers to 0.5 mm long. Weedy annual; in Victoria known only from Bogong High Plains
Ligule to 2 mm long (rarely to 5 mm and plants perennial in near-coastal areas); glumes longer than 2.5 mm long; anthers c. 1 mm long or more. Native perennials; widespread but rare in alps
Glumes swollen, hardened and shining near base; lemma (only c. 1.5 mm long) less than one-third as long as glumes, with conspicuous bent awn to 7 mm long
Glumes not swollen or hardened near base; lemma at least one-half as long as glumes
Panicle very dense, ovoid or spike-like; awn 7 mm or longer, rigid, erect, rather stout
Panicle loose or contracted or if ever spike-like, awn either less than 7 mm long, or slender and geniculate or sinuate
Glumes each with a slender awn c. 2 mm long
Glumes unawned, but acute or acuminate
Lemma papery, firmer than glumes, usually acute at apex; palea always well-developed; panicle sometimes spike-like
Lemma membranous, thinner than glumes, usually truncate (occasionally 4-toothed) at apex; palea sometimes absent or rudimentary; panicle never spike-like

Rachilla extension 30–100% of lemma length; inflorescence often breaking below the lowest branch and falling intact, acting as a wind-dispersed diaspore; palea well-developed at least 60% of lemma length;

Rachilla extension less than 20% of lemma length; inflorescence remaining intact until after spikelets mature; palea usually absent or minute (but developed in weedy, rhizomatous A. capillaris, A. gigantea and A. stololifera)
Fertile lemma awnless; inflorescence narrow-cylindric
Fertile lemma awned (sometimes the awn eariy-deciduous in Sorghum); inflorescence paniculate or of 2 or more narrow racemes
Spikelets of each pair unequally pedicellate, white and silky, in a dense fluffy narrow panicle; glumes never hooked

Spikelets green and glabrous partly recessed along rachis in 2-4 ranks; upper spikelet of each pair with pedicel partly fused to rachis, often appearing sessile; inner (or both) glumes of pedicellate spikelet commonly shortly hooked at apex

Awned bisexual floret bordered by a pair of unawned male spikelets, the 3 surrounded by an involucre of 4 male or barren spikelets; each aggregate of 7 spikelets subtended by a spathe-like bract and several of these combined into a pedunculate, nodding cluster within a sparse panicle (Kangaroo Grass)
Spikelets in pairs (lower sessile, upper shortly pedicellate)
Both spikelets in each pair awned and fertile; glumes covered with silky brown hairs
Only the sessile spikelet awned and fertile
Inflorescence a loose or dense panicle; spikelets somewhat plump at maturity
Inflorescence composed of 2 or more narrow spike-like racemes; spikelets strongly compressed dorsally, not plump at maturity
Racemes 2-6, erect or nodding, not subtended by spathe-like bracts
Racemes paired, one or more pairs arising from the axil of a spathe-like bract
Raceme pairs distinctly pedunculate; column of awn pubescent; lower glume of sessile spikelet rounded on back
Raceme pairs sessile or subsessile; column of awn glabrous; lower glume of sessile spikelet 2-keeled
Racemes erect or suberect at maturity; foliage not scented
Racemes deflexed at maturity; foliage somewhat lemon-scented
Nodes of culm encircled by a dense silky hairs 2 mm long or more; glumes not pitted; pedicels and rachis segments without a translucent median line
Nodes of culm glabrous or with rather sparse hairs to 1 mm long; glume of lower floret of each spikelet pair often deeply pitted dorsally; pedicels and rachis with a translucent median line

Male and female inflorescences separated on same plant; male spikelets in a loose terminal panicle; female spikelets arranged on a stout spike, remaining concealed within broad sheathing bracts in axils (maize or sweet corn); probably not in Victoria, see note below Poaceae description
Spikelets bisexual or if ever unisexual, both sexes mixed within inflorescence

Spikelets arising in 2s (occasionally in 3s) within inflorescence, unequally pedicellate or with 1 spikelet sessile and the other 1 or 2 spikelets pedicellate, the sessile and pedicellate spikelets usually dissimilar; fertile lemma and palea membranous, of thinner texture than glumes
Spikelets arising singly, or if ever paired (rarely), then spikelets similar; fertile lemma and palea of firmer texture than glumes (except in dense-flowered Neurachne of sandy soils in drier west)
Fertile lemma awnless; inflorescence narrow-cylindric
Fertile lemma awned (sometimes the awn eariy-deciduous in Sorghum); inflorescence paniculate or of 2 or more narrow racemes
Spikelets of each pair unequally pedicellate, white and silky, in a dense fluffy narrow panicle; glumes never hooked

Spikelets green and glabrous partly recessed along rachis in 2-4 ranks; upper spikelet of each pair with pedicel partly fused to rachis, often appearing sessile; inner (or both) glumes of pedicellate spikelet commonly shortly hooked at apex

Awned bisexual floret bordered by a pair of unawned male spikelets, the 3 surrounded by an involucre of 4 male or barren spikelets; each aggregate of 7 spikelets subtended by a spathe-like bract and several of these combined into a pedunculate, nodding cluster within a sparse panicle (Kangaroo Grass)
Spikelets in pairs (lower sessile, upper shortly pedicellate)
Both spikelets in each pair awned and fertile; glumes covered with silky brown hairs
Only the sessile spikelet awned and fertile
Inflorescence a loose or dense panicle; spikelets somewhat plump at maturity
Inflorescence composed of 2 or more narrow spike-like racemes; spikelets strongly compressed dorsally, not plump at maturity
Racemes paired, one or more pairs arising from the axil of a spathe-like bract
Racemes 2-6, erect or nodding, not subtended by spathe-like bracts
Raceme pairs distinctly pedunculate; column of awn pubescent; lower glume of sessile spikelet rounded on back
Raceme pairs sessile or subsessile; column of awn glabrous; lower glume of sessile spikelet 2-keeled
Racemes erect or suberect at maturity; foliage not scented
Racemes deflexed at maturity; foliage somewhat lemon-scented
Nodes of culm encircled by a dense silky hairs 2 mm long or more; glumes not pitted; pedicels and rachis segments without a translucent median line
Nodes of culm glabrous or with rather sparse hairs to 1 mm long; glume of lower floret of each spikelet pair often deeply pitted dorsally; pedicels and rachis with a translucent median line
Lower glume much reduced, represented by a bead-like swelling at the spikelet base
Lower glume sometimes reduced (absent in Axonopus, Paspalum and some Digitaria) but never appearing as a bead-like swelling

Inflorescence a dense, ovoid to cylindric, spike-like raceme 1-3 cm long; glumes equal to or longer than lemma, densely covered with silky blue-grey hairs on margin; rigid grass of mallee-scrub, drier heathland and woodlands in west
Inflorescence paniculate, or if spike-like, then glumes shorter than lemma
Upper glume truncate or emarginate, with a short point or awn arising from the notch, densely covered with pinkish silky hairs; panicle loose
Glumes unawned or tapered gradually to a distinctly terminal awn
Spikelet subtended by 1-many bristles or spines, almost as long as or longer than spikelet

Spikelets not subtended by bristles or spines (but racemes sometimes terminated by a slender point, which may be much longer than spikelets, and then the terminal spikelet apparently subtended by a bristle), if ever rachis hairy, then hairs much shorter than spikelet
Spikelets falling with spines or bristles attached
Spikelets falling free from spines or bristles which remain on the inflorescence axes
Bristles scabrous, completely surrounding the spikelet; inflorescence dense, spike-like
Bristles smooth, not completely surrounding the base of the spikelet; inflorescence of several one-sided racemes
Ligule absent
Ligule present, a fringe of hairs
Branches of inflorescence each terminated by a slender bristle
Branches of inflorescence terminated by a spikelet, or inflorescence unbranched (in Stenotaphrum)
Glumes and lemmas obtuse to acute, not narrow-acuminate or awn-tipped; upper lemma with transverse wrinkles
Glume(s) and/or lower lemma narrow-acuminate or awned; upper lemma without transverse wrinkles
Lower glume reduced, truncate; grasses of margins of watercourses and seasonally inundated ground
Lower glume long-awned, exceeding spikelet; delicate creeping grass of moist shaded lowland forests in east
Fertile lemma more or less covered with short downy hairs; scrambling grasses of eastern Victoria, often with the leaf-sheaths nodulose between the veins
Fertile lemma glabrous; habit various but leaf-sheaths not nodulose between veins
Inflorescence composed of one or more spikes or spike-like racemes with the spikelets arranged on one side only of the axis; axis often distinctly flattened
Inflorescence an open panicle, if ever apparently composed of spike-like racemes then the spikelets arranged all around the terete or angular axis
Spikelets in 2-4 rows, recessed into the flattened, 4-6 mm broad, rachis which breaks into segments at maturity; tough, rather thick-leaved stoloniferous perennial
Spikelets not recessed into rachis, falling free from it at maturity; branches of inflorescence sometimes angular but not distinctly flattened and never 6 mm broad

Inflorescence with slender racemes attached at or near the apex of the culm and radiating digitately from it; spikelets usually in pairs (1 pedicel longer than the other); outer glume reduced, abaxial (i.e. facing away from rachis); fertile lemma with flat, membranous margins
Inflorescence not digitate (but sometimes bifurcate); spikelets rarely paired; fertile lemma with thickened, inrolled margins
Lower glume absent or rudimentary (less than one-fifth as long as spikelet); spikelets flattened
Lower glume present, more than one-third as long as spikelet; spikelets biconvex, often plump
Glume on side of spikelet adjacent to rachis; tufted, shortly rhizomatous or semi-aquatic grasses
Lower (infertile) lemma on side of spikelet adjacent to rachis; creeping grass, occasionally escaping from lawns or pastures
Ligule present, a fringe of hairs
Ligule absent
Lower glume up to half the spikelet length, or if ever to 90% of spikelet length, then long-acuminate; upper glume not strongly ribbed; ligule distinctly ciliate, to 2.5 (mostly 0.5-1) mm long

Lower glume 60-90% as long as the spikelet, obtuse to acute; upper glume strongly ribbed by the thickened nerves; ligule membranous, sometimes minutely toothed at summit, but hardly ciliate, to 4 mm long
